segments.en: Numbered Discourses 11
1. Dependence
2. Making a Wish
“Mendicants, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethical conduct, need not make a wish:
‘May I have no regrets!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ sīlavato sīlasampannassa avippaṭisāro uppajjati.
segments.en: It’s only natural that an ethical person has no regrets.
When you have no regrets you need not make a wish:
‘May I feel joy!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ avippaṭisārissa pāmojjaṃ uppajjati.
segments.en: It’s only natural that joy springs up when you have no regrets.
When you feel joy you need not make a wish:
‘May I experience rapture!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ pamuditassa pīti uppajjati.
segments.en: It’s only natural that rapture arises when you’re joyful.
When your mind is full of rapture you need not make a wish:
‘May my body become tranquil!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ pītimanassa kāyo passambhati.
segments.en: It’s only natural that your body becomes tranquil when your mind is full of rapture.
When your body is tranquil you need not make a wish:
‘May I feel bliss!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati.
segments.en: It’s only natural to feel bliss when your body is tranquil.
When you feel bliss you need not make a wish:
‘May my mind be immersed in samādhi!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
segments.en: It’s only natural for the mind to become immersed in samādhi when you feel bliss.
When your mind is immersed in samādhi you need not make a wish:
‘May I truly know and see!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ samāhito yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati.
segments.en: It’s only natural to truly know and see when your mind is immersed in samādhi.

segments.pli: Yathābhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, jānato passato na cetanāya karaṇīyaṃ:
segments.en: When you truly know and see you need not make a wish:
‘May I grow disillusioned!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ nibbindati.
segments.en: It’s only natural to grow disillusioned when you truly know and see.
When you’re disillusioned you need not make a wish:
‘May I become dispassionate!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ nibbinno virajjati.
segments.en: It’s only natural to grow dispassionate when you’re disillusioned.
When you’re dispassionate you need not make a wish:
‘May I realize the knowledge and vision of freedom!’

segments.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ viratto vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ sacchikaroti.
segments.en: It’s only natural to realize the knowledge and vision of freedom when you’re dispassionate.

segments.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, virāgo vimuttiñāṇadassanattho vimuttiñāṇadassanānisaṃso, nibbidā virāgatthā virāgānisaṃsā, yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ nibbidatthaṃ nibbidānisaṃsaṃ, samādhi yathābhūtañāṇadassanattho yathābhūtañāṇadassanānisaṃso, sukhaṃ samādhatthaṃ samādhānisaṃsaṃ, passaddhi sukhatthā sukhānisaṃsā, pīti passaddhatthā passaddhānisaṃsā, pāmojjaṃ pītatthaṃ pītānisaṃsaṃ, avippaṭisāro pāmojjattho pāmojjānisaṃso, kusalāni sīlāni avippaṭisāratthāni avippaṭisārānisaṃsāni.
segments.en: And so, mendicants, the knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of dispassion. Dispassion is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment. Disillusionment is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing. Truly knowing and seeing is the purpose and benefit of immersion. Immersion is the purpose and benefit of bliss. Bliss is the purpose and benefit of tranquility. Tranquility is the purpose and benefit of rapture. Rapture is the purpose and benefit of joy. Joy is the purpose and benefit of not having regrets. Not having regrets is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics.

segments.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, dhammā dhamme abhisandenti, dhammā dhamme paripūrenti apārā pāraṃ gamanāyā”ti.
segments.en: And so, mendicants, good qualities flow on and fill up from one to the other, for going from the near shore to the far shore.”

sections.title: “Mendicants, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethical conduct,…

suttaplex.blurb: A virtuous person need not make a wish; it is natural for the path to flow on.
